properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY ISSUED FOR PRINCE GEORGE The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued a Dust Advisory for Prince George due to high concentrations of particulate matter (PM 2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure to PM 2.5 is particularily a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. The City of Prince Georgeâ€™s Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including backyard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits street sweeping activties (unless approved by an Authorized Person), recreational fires, and use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users). Industry is asked to reduce emissions wherever possible during the advisory. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-03T13:18:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-03T05:19:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3063246399.2019
Area: Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY ISSUED FOR VERNON April 2, 2019 - Vernon. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy, in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority, has issued a Dust Advisory for Vernon due to high concentrations of coarse particulates which are expected to persist until there is a change in current weather conditions. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air-conditioned spaces helps to reduce particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-03T12:48:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-03T04:49:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3923359640.2019

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-04T00:25:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T08:25:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3340056047.2019
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity, Labrador City and Wabush
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Marine Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Up to storm force westerly winds will develop over the estuary of the St. Lawrence this evening and will spread toward Anticosti Island overnight. These winds will reach 40 to 60 knots and will usher in colder air, will produce wave heights of 3 to 6 metres along with freezing spray. Marine conditions will be particularly hazardous for the small crafts in this early fishing season. Conditions will improve gradually on Friday. ###
Expires: 2019-04-03T22:39:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T06:40:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2010379305.2019
Area: Pointe Ã  Michel to Pointe-des-Monts, Tadoussac to Pointe Ã  Michel, Pointe-des-Monts to Anticosti - northern half, Pointe-des-Monts to Anticosti - southern half
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent flurries are expected to develop early on Thursday with occasional snow squalls. Very strong winds and falling temperatures may combine with fresh snowfall to cause localized blizzard-like conditions over some areas. Snowfall accumulations near 5 can be expected by Thursday evening, with likely similar amounts again on Thursday night. Flurries and potential for snow squalls will persist until Friday morning along coastal areas and until Friday evening inland. Further snowfall accumulations are possible Friday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:55:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T07:56:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1305951932.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system approaching from the south will bring snow, blowing snow and strong winds to the region Wednesday night. At this point it is a bit early to try and predict exact snowfall amounts but it does appear warnings will be required in some areas. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-03T19:46:40-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A storm will cross the Gulf of St Lawrence over the next couple of days. It will give 10 to 15 centimetres of snow over the north shore of the GaspÃ© Peninsula between Wednesday afternoon and the following night. Then, high westerly winds will develop late in the night in the wake of the storm, causing blowing snow significantly reducing visibilities locally and bringing a rapid drop in temperatures. These poor conditions will continue through Thursday, making for hazardous driving conditions due to poor visibility and potentially icy and slippery roads. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T17:52:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T01:53:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1008036297.2019
Area: Matane, Grande-VallÃ©e area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with total accumulations of 15 to 30 centimetres is expected. A storm will pass through the Gulf of St Lawrence on Wednesday and Thursday. It will bring snow heavy at times over the southeastern areas of the GaspÃ© Peninsula midday Wednesday that will spread to the Lower North Shore early Wednesday evening. The snow will taper off Thursday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A storm over the Maritimes is tracking across the Gulf of St Lawrence today and will reach the Labrador coast on Thursday. It will give 15 to 25 centimetres of snow by Thursday morning over these regions. Later on, behind the system, strong to high winds will reduce visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Les SuÃªtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will track across Nova Scotia this evening then cross the Gulf of St. Lawrence overnight. Very strong Les Suetes winds gusting up 160 km/h are forecast to develop this afternoon and then end late this evening when the wind shifts to southwesterly. A general wind warning will remain in effect overnight and Thursday as southwesterly winds are expected to gust up to 100 km/h. ### High winds may result in power outages and fallen tree branches. Les SuÃªtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:24:56-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will track through the Gulf of St. Lawrence tonight. Southeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h are expected late this afternoon and this evening. Winds will shift to southwesterly near midnight and gust to 100 km/h overnight. Southwesterly winds 70 gusting to 100 km/h are expected to persist Thursday and Thursday evening. Winds will veer to westerly overnight and slowly diminish on Friday. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:29:30-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An intense low pressure system will track across Nova Scotia this evening then cross the Gulf of St. Lawrence overnight. Snow mixed with rain will develop over Prince Edward Island this morning then change to rain at times heavy near noon, with the rain occasionally mixed with ice pellets. Over Prince County, a period of accumulating snow is forecast before changing to rain mixed with snow or ice pellets in the afternoon. Rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 millimetres are forecast before tapering to scattered flurries late this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:30:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T07:31:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3116704732.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind gusts causing widespread damage are expected or occurring. Strong southeasterly winds will develop today with gusts reaching up to 150 km/h over areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies tonight. Winds will shift to strong southwesterlies with gusts between 100 and 120 km/h before morning Thursday. These winds are expected to persist through until Thursday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An intense low pressure system will track across Nova Scotia this evening then cross the Gulf of St. Lawrence overnight. Rain at times heavy will develop early this morning over southwestern Nova Scotia and quickly spread to the remainder of the province by this afternoon. The rain will be mixed with snow to start over parts of mainland Nova Scotia this morning. Over Cape Breton, the rain will likely be preceded by a period of snow over some areas. Rainfall amounts will be highest over Atlantic coastal regions of mainland Nova Scotia where 50 to 70 millimetres are forecast. Elsewhere, 25 to 40 millimetres of rain is expected. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:31:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T07:32:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3314960512.2019

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-03T15:17:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-03T07:18:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1769619895.2019
Area: Bulkley Valley and The Lakes - southeast including Burns Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense low pressure system will track through the Gulf of St. Lawrence this evening. East to southeasterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h are forecast to develop over Cape Breton and eastern mainland Nova Scotia this afternoon. Winds will shift to southwesterly and diminish slightly Wednesday evening but are still expected to gust to 70 or 80 km/h overnight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:37:19-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### Children, including teenagers, are at higher risk from outdoor air pollution because they often spend time being active outdoors. Young people are more likely to have asthma and their lungs are still developing. For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-03T15:18:49-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. A storm over the Maritimes is tracking across the Gulf of St Lawrence today and will reach the Labrador coast on Thursday. It will give 25 to 40 centimetres of snow by Thursday morning over the Lower North Shore. Later on, behind the system, high westerly winds gusting up to 100 km/h will develop and reduce visibilities in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind gusts are expected or occurring. Very strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 140 km/h will develop near noon today. Winds will further increase in the evening to near 180 km/h before shifting to strong southwesterly winds with gusts up to 100 km/h early morning Thursday. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at high risk of being overturned. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow at times heavy is expected to develop this evening and taper to flurries Thursday morning, with flurries continuing through Thursday night. At this time, snowfall amounts of 20 to 40 cm are expected. Strong east to southeast winds will develop tonight, with gusts to 100 km/h along parts of the coast early Thursday. These gusty winds combined with the heavy snow will result in reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Persistent flurries and snow squalls are expected to develop early on Thursday and persist until Friday evening. Very strong winds and falling temperatures will combine with fresh snowfall to cause intermittent blizzard-like conditions over most areas. Snowfall accumulations between 5 and 15 cm can be expected by Thursday evening, with likely similar amounts again on Thursday night. Flurries and snow squalls will persist on Friday. Although winds may be slightly weaker, visibility is not likely to improve until Friday evening when flurries are expected to dissipate. Further snowfall accumulations are possible. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:55:29-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. An intensifying low pressure system will move northeastward across Nova Scotia tonight and into the Gulf of St. Lawrence overnight. Snow will begin early this morning over southwestern New Brunswick and then spread quickly across the province by noon. The snow is expected to mix with rain this afternoon over parts of southeastern New Brunswick. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected, with the highest amounts over northeastern regions of the province. The precipitation will taper off this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T23:35:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-03T07:36:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2472229436.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant early spring storm will bring rain and snow to much of New Brunswick today. An intensifying low pressure system will move northeastward across Nova Scotia tonight and into the Gulf of St. Lawrence overnight. Snow will begin this morning over southwestern New Brunswick and then mix with or change to rain before ending this afternoon. Snowfall amounts of up to 10 cm are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
